document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the genus Osbornellus Ball (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) in Central America 2702

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the genus Osbornellus Ball (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) in Central America 2702

bibRefCitation.author: Linnavuori, R. E.
bibRefCitation.refString: Linnavuori, R. E. (1959) Revision of the Neotropical Deltocephalinae and some related subfamilies (Homoptera). Annales Zoologici Societatis Zoologicae Botanicae Fennicae ' Vanamo' 20 (1), 45 - 51.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Redescription. Length: 5.2–5.7 mm . Member of the
O. auronitens
group ( Fig. 1a ). Vertex roundly angulate, median length less than distance between eyes at posterior margin. White band along anterior margin between ocelli, bordered anteriorly and posteriorly by dark brown bands. Narrow white area across median half of vertex behind marginal lines, bordered posteriorly by narrow brown line at apex of coronal suture. Broad, bright orange band across vertex between anterior portions of eyes. White band along posterior margin with few faint brown dots on anterior edge, short longitudinal brown line at each end. Pronotum light yellow with orange band along anterior margin, with bright orange dot in center, and opaque orange band near posterior margin, interrupted at center by lighter colored longitudinal stripe. Scutellum opaque yellow with large orange spots in basal angles, small white spots at apices of basal angles and halfway along lateral margins. Anterior wing transparent, yellowish, with some pale brown dots along costa and commissural line; apices marked with brown.

Diagnosis. Very similar to
O . springerae
, but in ventral view the ventral processes of
O. anonae
arise from the middle part of the shaft and are separated from the shaft. In
O. springerae
the ventral processes arise one-third of the way along the shaft. In
O. anonae
the shaft is less curved and is close to the ventral processes near the apex; the dorsal projection is less conspicous than in
O. springerae .
Distribution. Known from Mexico , Costa Rica , Nicaragua and Panama ; 50–1500 m .
